raw_text:
First look at PlayStation 3 chip
 
 Some details of the chip inside Sony's PlayStation 3 have been revealed.
 
 Sony, IBM and Toshiba have released limited data about the so-called Cell chip that will be able to carry out trillions of calculations per second. The chip will be made of several different processing cores that work on tasks together. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006 but developers are expecting to get prototypes early next year to tune games that will appear on it at launch.
 
 The three firms have been working on the chip since 2001 but before now few details have been released about how it might function. In a joint statement the three firms gave hints about how the chip will work but fuller details will be released in February next year at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco.
 
 The three firms claim that the Cell chip will be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors. When put inside powerful computer servers, the Cell consortium expects it to be capable of handling 16 trillion floating point operations, or calculations, every second. The chip has also been refined to be able to handle the detailed graphics common in games and the data demands of films and broadband media. IBM said it would start producing the chip in early 2005 at manufacturing plants in the US. The first machines off the line using the Cell processor will be computer workstations and servers. A working version of the PS3 is due to be shown off in May 2005 but a full launch of the next generation console is not expected to start until 2006. As well as being inside the PlayStation 3, the chip will also be used inside high-definition TVs and powerful computers. "In the future, all forms of digital content will be converged and fused onto the broadband network," said Ken Kutaragi, Chief Operating Officer of Sony. "Current PC architecture is nearing its limits."
llama3.2:1b: Sony's PlayStation 3 chip is based on a Cell processor that can handle trillions of calculations per second, with three firms working together since 2001 to refine it.
The chip will be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors and capable of handling large amounts of data, including graphics and movie data.
llama3.2:3b: Sony, IBM and Toshiba have released limited data on their Cell chip, a multi-core processor expected to handle trillions of calculations per second, set to be used in the PlayStation 3, computer workstations, servers, high-definition TVs and computers.
The chip is claimed to be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors and will be refined for gaming graphics and data demands.
gemma2:2b: Sony's Cell chip for PlayStation 3 will provide processing power up to 10 times that of existing processors, enabling trillions of calculations per second.
The chip, developed by Sony, IBM, and Toshiba, is designed for high-demand tasks like video game development and multimedia content creation.
It will be used in the next generation PS3 console and other applications such as high-definition TVs and powerful computers.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:

  * Sony, IBM, and Toshiba are working on a Cell chip inside PlayStation 3.
* The cell chip will be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors.
* The cell chip can handle trillions of calculations per second.
* It will work with powerful computer servers and handle detailed graphics common in games.
* The first version off the line for the PS3 console is expected to be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Sony's PlayStation 3 uses a Cell processor made by IBM and Toshiba, expected to be unveiled in early 2005 with prototypes available next year for tuning games.

It promises ten times the power of current processors, capable of handling up to 16 trillion floating point operations per second and supporting detailed graphics and data demands in films and broadband media.
The chip will also integrate into high-definition TVs and powerful computers, potentially fusing digital content onto a single network channel starting in the future.
qwen2.5:3b: First look at PlayStation 3 chip reveals a powerful Cell processor with up to 10 times more power than existing processors.
Expected to handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second and support detailed game graphics, films, and broadband media.
IBM claims it will start producing the chip in early 2005 at US manufacturing plants.
PlayStation 3 is expected to launch in 2006; first prototypes are due for developers next year.
The chip will also be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers.
Sony predicts all digital content will converge on broadband networks, necessitating a shift from current PC architecture.
opencoder:1.5b: Some details revealed by Sony's PlayStation 3 have been made publicly available for analysis.
IBM and Toshiba have begun work on the Cell chip that may be able to handle trillions of calculations per second.
The chip is expected in 2006, but firm expectations are underway to get prototypes at launch.
In February 2021, an international conference titled 'International Solid State Circuits' was held, which furthered its development and production.
The three firms have been working on the chip since 2001, but only minimal information has been released about how it might function in the coming years."
smollm:1.7b: The PlayStation 3 chip has several key features that make it a powerful processor for handling demanding tasks.

The chip is expected to be able to handle trillions of floating point operations per second (FLOPS) and will be capable of handling the detailed graphics common in games, as well as the data demands of films and broadband media.
The three firms claim that the Cell chip will be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors, which is a significant increase from current processors.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Sony's PlayStation 3 will feature a chip from IBM and Toshiba, claimed to be up to ten times more powerful than existing processors.
The cell chip could handle trillions of calculations per second in servers and detailed graphics.
Sony expects the PS3 demo next year, with first machines in early 2005 for workstations and servers.
IBM starts manufacturing the chip in 2005, expected for computers like workstations and servers.
tinyllama:1.1b: Sony has revealed limited data about PlayStation 3's Cell chip, which is set to carry out trillions of calculations per second.
The Cell chip will function as a multi-processing core with several processing cores working together to perform tasks that are more demanding than previous chips.
The PlayStation 3 will use the Cell chip, along with other improvements aimed at handling data-intensive games and media content in high-definition TVs and personal computers.
Sony is expected to show off a version of the console in May 2005 as well as unveil a full release for the next-generation console later in 2006.
The Cell chip will also be used in high-definition TVs, set top boxes, and other digital content platforms.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Cell chip for PlayStation 3 is made up of several processing cores working together to perform trillions of calculations per second.
These cores are designed to handle complex tasks in games and multimedia applications like movies, animation and digital imagery.
Sony claims the new chip will be more powerful than existing high-end processors, providing a level of computational power not seen before.
The Cell chip will also play an important role in future entertainment systems such as high-definition TVs and powerful computers.
In fact, IBM is planning to start producing the chip in early 2005 for use in computer workstations and servers.
Meanwhile, Sony is planning to show off a preliminary version of the PlayStation 3 at a special event in May, with a full launch expected in 2006.

The chip has several processing cores that work together and will be inside the PlayStation 3, high-definition TVs, and powerful computers.
It's expected to be more than 10 times more powerful than existing processors and is being refined for detailed graphics in games and data demands in films and broadband media.
The Cell consortium expects it to handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second.
IBM plans to start producing the chip in early 2005 at manufacturing plants in the US, but a full launch of the next generation console won't begin until

The chip will be able to handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second and will be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers as well as inside the PlayStation 3 console.
IBM will start manufacturing the chip in early 2005 before it is used in the PlayStation 3.

The Cell chip will also be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers, with production starting in early 2005.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Sony, IBM, and Toshiba have revealed limited details about the Cell chip in the PlayStation 3, which can perform trillions of calculations per second using multiple processing cores.
The chip, in development since 2001, is expected to be 10 times more powerful than existing processors and will handle advanced graphics and media demands.
IBM will begin production in early 2005, with initial applications in workstations and servers.
A prototype PS3 will be shown in May 2005, with a full launch in 2006.
The chip will also be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers, supporting the convergence of digital content on broadband networks.
stablelm2:1.6b: Sony, IBM, and Toshiba jointly revealed limited data about their PlayStation 3 chip called Cell, capable of performing trillions of calculations per second.
The processing cores work together, creating a powerful chip that can handle detailed graphics and multimedia demands.
The Cell chip will be up to 10 times more powerful than existing processors and will be used in high-definition TVs and powerful computers.
IBM will produce the chips in early 2025 with computer workstations and servers as the first machines off the line using the Cell processor.
A full launch of the next generation console is expected in 2026 or later, while a working version of PS3 is shown off by May 2025.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Sony, IBM, and Toshiba have collaborated on the development of the Cell chip for PlayStation 3 since 2001.
This powerful processor, expected in 2006, will perform trillions of calculations per second, 10 times more than current processors.
The Cell chip features multiple processing cores working together to manage complex tasks, including detailed graphics for games and data demands of films and broadband media.
IBM began production at U.S. manufacturing plants in early 2005, targeting computer workstations and servers first.
A prototype of the PS3 is set for display in May 2005, with full launch delayed until 2006.

Beyond gaming consoles, the Cell chip will also power high-definition TVs and advanced computers, marking a convergence of digital content on broadband networks as current PC architecture approaches its limits.
